Internal network traffic communicating w.Action: Obtain a list of newly registered domains similar to organizational domains or common services using external sources (WHOIS, passive DNS). Query Zeek dns.log and conn.log for internal lookups and connections to these domains. Use correlation analysis to identify endpoints/users frequently interacting with suspicious similar domains.

Obtain a list of newly registered domains with low reputation or flagged by Threat Intelligence feeds/passive DNS. Query Zeek dns.log and conn.log for internal lookups and connections to these domains. Use descriptive statistics on connection volume and duration for these domains to identify unusual patterns (e.g., high volume, persistent connections indicative of C2).

Domains resolved or contacted by interna.Data: Zeek dns.log; Zeek conn.log; Windows Event ID 4624; Windows Event ID 4688
Domains resolved or contacted by interna.Action: For hosts/users flagged by other behavioral anomalies (identified via Windows Event IDs or other means), analyze their historical Zeek dns.log and conn.log activity. Use time series analysis to identify communication with domains that deviate significantly from their established baseline frequency, volume, or timing patterns. Flag interactions with domains occurring outside of normal business hours or during periods of inactivity.

Domains exhibiting Fast Flux characteris.Action: Analyze Zeek dns.log to monitor the number of unique IP addresses a domain resolves to over time. Use statistical methods (e.g., calculating the number of unique IPs per domain per hour) to identify domains resolving to an unusually high number of IPs within a short timeframe (Fast Flux). Additionally, examine Zeek conn.log for connections to resolved domains occurring on ports or protocols not commonly associated with standard services (e.g., ports > 1024), using frequency analysis to identify rare port usage for domains.
